comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content:
Anna Pavlova (Pavlovna) (1881?-1931) was a Russian ballerina. She joined the Imperial Ballet in 1899 and became a prima ballerina in 1906. Her American debut was made with Mikhail Mordkin, on March 1, 1910, at the Metropolitan Opera House, New York City, in a revival of Delibes's ballet, Coppelia. After the debut a New York critic declared such dancing had not been seen on the local stage during the present generation and praised the supreme ease with which Pavlova executed the most difficult tricks of the dancer's art. After 1913, she danced independently with her own company around the world. Some of her more famous dances include The Dragon fly, Californian Poppy, and Gavotte. "Pavlova is perhaps most renowned for creating the role of "The Dying Swan", a solo choreographed for her by Michel Fokine. The ballet, created in 1905, is danced to Le cygne from The Carnival of the Animals by Camille Saint-Saëns." Pavlova was married to her accompanist, Victor d'Andre. The marriage was announced by the dancer during her last American tour in 1924-25, which was said to be her farewell appearance in this country. Commenting on her marriage at that time, the dancer said:
"For an artist there is no husband. Pavlova the artist and Pavlova the wife, they are two very different persons, so I keep them separate. My dancing belongs to the world, but my husband to myself."
Anna died of pleurisy at the height of her fame in 1931. She is considered one of the finest classical ballet dancers in history. [1] [2] [3] [4]

comment._content: In February 1915, she was dancing in New York, at the Century, with the Ballet Russe. See ad highlighting PAVLOWA at lower left of chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1915-02-15/ed-...

comment.author: 70875173@N00
comment._content: if she was born 1881 and died 1931, how could she die at age 45?

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/70875173@N00] gov_calif – Thanks for (as they say) "doing the math" ;) The birth date of 1881 came from the Wikipedia reference (#2 above), while the "died at ... age 45" came from The New York Times reference (#3 above). The Times, in that January 23, 1931, article listed her date of birth as Jan. 31, 1885. Several other U.S. papers reporting on her death gave the same information. A further look into Anna's date of birth produces inconclusive results. In addition to differences in the year, there are differences between the month and day as a result of Old Style (O.S.) and New Style (N.S.) dates: February 12 [O.S. January 31]. A Times book review of 'Margot Fonteyn': Leaping Beauty, gives Anna's birth year as 1882. A Times movie review of the 1984 movie, "Pavlova -- A Woman For All Time", lists her birth as "1882?". Classical Ballet News mentions both the January 31st and February 12th dates, and gives the year as 1881, commenting that she died "a few days shy of her 50th birthday". Google's search results summary is "Best guess for Anna Pavlova Date of birth is February 12, 1881 -- Mentioned on at least 4 websites including wikipedia org, imdb com and topsynergy com " For their part, this past February, Google celebrated Anna's 131st birthday on February 12, 2012, with a Google Doodle:                         In an article entitled "Anna Pavlova: Ballerina Absoluta", originally published in The Ave Maria, Malana Mercurio wrote:
"Anna Pavlova was born in St. Petersburg, premature and frail, sometime in the early 1880s. The exact year is not certain and if Anna herself knew, she never told anyone. She was the only child of poor parents and had the misfortune to lose her father, reputed to have been shiftless, when she was two."
"Born sometime in the early 1880s" sounds good to me -- and perhaps someone else will have more information. In the meantime I have removed the reference to her age ("died at ... age 45") from the comment above, and changed the birth date to "?".
